comments.text:
User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 6.1; en-GB; rv:1.9.2.13) Gecko/20101203 Firefox/3.6.13
Build Identifier: 1.0b2 plug-in for Thunderbird

View multiple read-write calendars simulateously, say "Home" and "Foobar". Copy an event from Foobar and paste it on a different day. It should paste, by default into calendar Foobar. It doesn't - it goes to Home. 


The above applies even if the checkbox next to "Home" in the "Calendar" window is unchecked. In this case, the event invisibly goes into Home, reappearing only once "Home" is checked.

Reproducible: Always

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create & view multiple read-write calendars simultaneously in the normal fashion, where one is the default calendar called Home.
2. Create an event, specifying that it is in a calendar other than Home
3. Copy the event
4. Select a different day and paste the event
5. Uncheck the box next to "Home" in the "Calendar" window, so that only events in Foobar appear
6. Copy an event
7. Paste it on a different day
Actual Results:  
The event pastes into calendar "Home", not the calendar from which it was copied. If "Home" is not being viewed, then he pasted event does not appear until "Home" is viewed.

Expected Results:  
The event should go, by default, into the calendar from which it was copied. It should go into another calendar only if the calendar from which it was copied is read-only.

The bug was detected while using add-on Provider For Google Calendar 0.7.1, though I think the bug is more likely in the core Calendar code than the add-on.

The hidden calendar doesn't get visible due to Bug 482110.

comments.text:
@Stefan. "The target calendar for new events or paste operations is the calendar that is selected"... Why? Why pasting is equaled to a new event? It is not - it's a copy of an old one. 
I understand completely why this behavior is _considered_ as logical and helpful for adding NEW events. I admit it does this work well in my case (see below).
But it is based on the assumption that someone switches between calendars when working with Lightning/Sunbird. But is there empirical evidence that that is the case? Any usability research? 

I can only speak for myself: 
- I have 4 calendars (in order of how often events are created and modified): 1. Appointments with clients, 
2. Business appointments, 
3. Clients' birthdays and 
4. Personal...
- I have set "Appointments with clients" as "default" calendar and do not switch between those calendars at all. . That means that when i create a new appointment, in most cases i don't have to change the calendar. 
- I even got rid of left pane altogether - it just takes space and has no real use.

So far so good. But only this far!!!

I use copy and paste in calendars 1, 2 en 4. And events are ALWAYS copied within a calendar and NEVER across calendars. And then, all of a sudden my personal events become "Appointments with clients"... It's counter intuitive and i'd say counter common sense! After all, "calendar" is property of an event.
There is another side to it. There are three other locations where people track and modify my "Appointments with clients" calendar... so having my personal stuff exposed there is at least unprofessional...

Again, this is my case, but i am convinced that most other people have the same (no need for cross calendar copying of events). It's a natural thing... 

I hope you guys can reconsider the "intended behavior" or give us a choice - some boolean configuration setting like "Copy & pase to the same calendar".

comments.raw_text: I wanted to report this behaviour as a bug too. I understand that it is logical to use the default calendar when the data being pasted stems from an outside source. But when you copy an existing event from another calendar (e.g. a birthday), IMHO it is more intuitive to paste this into the same calendar and not into the default one.
